title: 115_s3555
content: The "Elder Pride Act of 2018" includes definitions for LGBT individuals and establishes an Office of Older LGBT Policy. The "Elder Pride Act of 2018" establishes an Office of Older LGBT Policy within the Administration to coordinate services for older LGBT individuals. The "Elder Pride Act of 2018" establishes an Office of Older LGBT Policy to coordinate services for older LGBT individuals, including promoting federal policies, supporting research in LGBT aging, and collecting information on challenges faced by older LGBT individuals. The "Elder Pride Act of 2018" establishes an Office of Older LGBT Policy to coordinate services for older LGBT individuals, recommend policies, promote culturally competent care, administer grants, and submit reports to Congress on activities every five years. The Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include a Rural Outreach Grant Program under Part A of title IV. The Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include definitions for key terms such as Director, Eligible entity, and Rural area. Eligible entities can include states, agencies, organizations, or institutions focusing on serving older or LGBT individuals in rural areas. The purpose of this section is to provide resources and incentives for eligible entities to create a strategy for connecting with older LGBT individuals in rural areas. The Director can grant funds for approved activities, and eligible entities must submit applications with required information. An application for a grant under this section must include a description of proposed activities, the population in a rural area served, resources available, intent to partner with local organizations, and evidence of meeting urgent needs not addressed by existing sources. The Director requires specific information and certifications for grant applications, including activities approved for creating partnerships with older LGBT individuals in rural areas. Approved activities may involve education, community outreach, reducing isolation, and improving access to care. The Director requires specific information and certifications for grant applications, including activities approved for creating partnerships with older LGBT individuals in rural areas to reduce isolation, improve access to care, foster relationships with service providers, enhance cultural competency, and expand non-discrimination policies. The Director establishes standards and guidelines for approved activities supported by grants, allowing eligible entities to adapt them as needed. Entities receiving grants must cooperate with relevant state and local agencies serving older LGBT individuals. The Director sets standards for approved activities funded by grants, requiring cooperation with state and local agencies serving older LGBT individuals. Eligible entities prioritize working with organizations serving economically underserved populations. Reports on activities must be submitted to Congress every two fiscal years.
